Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 03:34PM awjkej wrote: Hi Diane, I support getting a new onc too.  You need someone who is helping you and there for you.  I changed oncs within my medical group (I am in California).  I routinely get second opinions.  My insurance usu. pays for one and then if I need a third opinion, I usu. pay out-of-pocket for the appt.  It is worth every penny...knowledge is power! Have you considered a PET/CT?  If you are diagnosed with bone mets, this is a good diagnostic test to have along with your others. Here is the link for the CBCN - Canadian Breast Cancer Network list of Breast Cancer Support Groups.  http://www.cbcn.ca/en/?section=6&category=255 Also this link which lists support groups for Calgary http://research.cancer.ca/ccs/internet/standard/0,3182,3225_358267__langId-en,00.html Maybe you will find help from one in your area which could help you in this process. Hugs, Anne
Posts.Title: Steps for second opinion or search for new Onc. Danie awjkej

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 04:04PM awjkej wrote: Hi Ladies, Getting the news that your cancer has spread knocks the wind out of you and can bring on an anxiety that is unfathomable.  But the good news, yes there can be good news, is that many stage 4 is treated like a chronic disease now.  This is because of the targeted therapies out there, and there are many, and many more coming up which are in clinical trials now. I just celebrated my 5 year from initial diagnosis and 4 years from bone mets diagnosis with a NED PET/CT scan for the first time :-).  I have 3 boys and an active life, and yes I have had to make changes to my lifestyle, but I am here! Every one of my treatments and procedures has been worth it, and I plan on being here for a long time! Jen - It would be helpful to know what your cancer characteristics are so we can help with more information and support for you.  Just know that you are not alone, and you will find tremendous support here. Hugs, Anne
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed stage 4 Jen53 awjkej

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 05:59PM awjkej wrote: AnnNYC, I totally agree with you.  The treatments today for stage 4 are more targeted at the particular cancer, the person's lifestyle, and their quality of life.  When I was first diagnosed, the treatment I had was considered very aggressive.  By the time I finished my chemo treatments, the protocol had already changed, and it keeps changing with all the new clinical trials coming to fruition in order to best fit the person's cancer, needs and wants.  In addition to the medical treatment I get, I also have changed my diet to include a CAM regimen, wheat grass shots, lots of green tea, no caffene, no alcohol, no sugar, well almost none :-).  So I do alittle of everything. Stage 4 cancer is being more and more treated like a chronic disease because there are so many ways to approach the cancer.  There is much hope, and much reason for hope today!  I don't want to disregard anyone's feelings b/c believe me, I had my share of panic attacks in the beginning as it is a shock to your very core.  Cancer is now part of who I am, but it doesn't define me. Anne
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed stage 4 Jen53 awjkej

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 02:03PM awjkej wrote: Hi Ladies,  I have not been here for a few years as I managed the mets and volunteered to help others in my community.  But the discussion boards have always been close to my heart recommending them to anyone whom I thought would benefit.   I find myself back here today and it is like coming home again even though I do not know anyone :)  I am about to start TDM1/Kadcyla as my mets in my lung tissue has progressed. The difficulty breathing has increased and I am trying to keep the fear at bay and a positive attitude.  The other mets in my bones are stable.   I have read of the varying side effects, which I usually can handle, and am hoping that I see good results from Kadcyla :)

Posts.Content: awjkej wrote: Hi All, Well after a second opinion re treatment, and after discussing options with my oncologist, I decided on the standard option of tykerb and xeloda instead of a Phase II trial for tykerb and avastin. I was really interested in in the trial, but I would have to travel every 3 weeks. With my current family obligations, and our 3 boys all in school, it would be too much. But if I don't do well on the tykerb/xeloda I can always see if the trial is still available. So we will see how it goes and hopefully my bone mets in my hip and spine will remain stable and hopefully the new meds will take care of the node near my bronchial tubes. The extra good news...always looking for that silver lining ...is that the node is NOT in my lungs and I have good ventilation and they are clear!!!! Thank you again for support, feedback and good wishes, Anne www.faithhopecourage.com / Faith is the bird that feels the light when the dawn is still dark.--Rabindranath Tagore Dx 1/10/2003, IDC, Left, 2cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 0/14 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ (FISH) Surgery 2/3/2003 Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 3/27/2003 AC Targeted Therapy 10/1/2004 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Hormonal Therapy 12/1/2004 Arimidex (anastrozole) Chemotherapy 11/4/2005 Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 11/21/2005 Bone Hormonal Therapy 6/16/2006 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 8/9/2007 Tykerb (lapatinib) Chemotherapy 8/9/2007 Xeloda (capecitabine) Radiation Therapy 10/17/2007 Bone Chemotherapy 4/8/2008 Navelbine (vinorelbine) Radiation Therapy 11/10/2010 Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Decided on next treatment awjkej A-M_Higgins

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 11:27AM awjkej wrote: You have received excellent advice from these caring ladies.  I believe the herceptin did work by slowing down progression, and there are times when it does better paired with another drug.   My mets that had progressed in my lung tissue are now acting up and we are switching to TDM1/Kadcyla to hopefully kick them down.  I am 10 years out from initial diagnosis and 9 years out from mets diagnosis, and many combination of drugs have kept my cancer at bay/slowed down.   The very hard part, the very hard reality is that the mets will never "go away", but my hope is to manage them with drugs available.

Posts.Title: How Many Are We? zarovka SimonH

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2008 09:27PM awjkej wrote: Just to add to the variables.  I had a bone scan which showed nothing, and then I had a PET/CT (done in combo)that showed my bone mets, and the spot on my chest (just outside my lungs) the PET/CT is a clear indicator of my mets progression and other than any pain I feel, is the only indicator.  Tumor marker blood tests don't work either.  I have now had 13 PET/CT scans since 2004.  When I get my PET/CT scan, I am always scanned from my head/brain down to just past my knee.  I haven't ever had a brain MRI I believe all owing to the fact that the PET/CT works for me. I have a friend who just had bilateral mastectomy.  They were watching a few small spots, did biopsies etc which led to the surgery.  She also had an MRI done right before surgery.  In the pathology work up from surgery, they found a 5.2 mm tumor that had never showed up on the MRI..scarey!  We are all so different, and our make ups are so different, that it constantly amazes me how so many tests can deliver such a wide variety of results. Anne
Posts.Title: PET Scan vs, Bone Scan JoyRebecca nuclear1

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 07:45PM awjkej wrote: Hi Carolyn, I was initially diagnosed in Jan 2003 with breast cancer.  I am ER+/PR+ and her2/neu+++.  Went through 6 rounds of Adriamycin/Cytoxan, hair fell out etc.   In the Fall of 2004, after a back ache that would go away, I had xrays done and showed bone mets in my spine and left hip, and a node in my chest.  I will be going for my 15th PET/CT scan on Wednesday to check the status.  As mentioned above, my cancer is treated as a chronic disease so when it acts up, we change treatment to knock it back down.  The PET/CT scan is the only diagnostic tool that works for me, so I get them every 3-4 months.  I was diagnosed at age 43, and will be 48 this Fall.  I am hoping to be around a long long time!  I have 3 boys ages 15, 11, and 8 and I am able to keep up with them for the most part :-).  I told my husband I had to stick around to make sure he raised them properly...ha ha!  Please know that your feelings of panic are normal.  When I was diagnosed with the bone mets, we drove to San Francisco for a second opinion regarding treatment, and on the way home to the Sacramento area, I had my first panic attack.  Now 5 years out, I still get scared at times, but I know how to take care of myself, and I usu. come here for reassurance . So if you do have cancer, and I am hoping not, but if you do, please know that the diagnosis isn't a death sentence.  The treatment that I originally did in 2003 was considered aggressive for me at the time.  Soon after finishing the treatment, they weren't doing it anymore because of the new drugs and treatments found through clinical trials. My cancer is treated like a chronic disease, and my treatments now focus on maintaining my quality of life, and keeping the cancer at bay.  Sending you good thoughts and hugs, Anne

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2008 02:37PM awjkej wrote: Hi Bonnie, After finding out that the tykerb/xeloda treatment regimen I am on is working, my onc said we will just stay on it for the foreseeable future.  I don't know if this qualifies as maintenance as what you are thinking, but I take 500mg twice a day along with 1000mg tykerb once a day.  I do xeloda one week on one week off. Posts.Title: Xeloda as maintenance drug Bonnielv Tracy1964

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 04:45PM awjkej wrote: Hi, I am sorry that your cancer has returned.  I too thought that after my initial treatment, everything was done and over with.  But less than a year later I was diagnosed with bone mets.   I don't have ogliometastatic breast cancer.  I have bone mets to my spine and hip, with a spot in my perihilar region.  Currently I am NED for the very first time.  I am ER+/PR+, her2/neu +++, orig dianosed in Jan 2003, bone mets diagnosed Fall 2004.  I had bilateral with no reconstruction and oophorectomy. I was on weekly herceptin for 2 years, and during that time I had 9 months of taxotere - my bones loved it, meaning it kept the cancer at bay.  The spot on my chest grew, so I am now on xeloda/tykerb daily pills.  I also take aromasin daily. Zometa for my bone every 3 months.  Monitor activity with PET/CT scans When I first started herceptin, I felt like I had the flu for a few days, but after the first few months I didn't have any side effects.  I had relatively no side effects from the taxotere, which I am told is unusual.  I had similar reaction to the zometa as I did the herceptin.  For the most part, I had to deal with fatigue and monitored my activity level accordingly. I have heard good things about the carboplatin and taxotere.  I also know there are so many targeted therapies out there, and many options to discuss with your oncologist. Hugs, Anne
Posts.Title: Help! Looking for someone who has been through the same thing! lburchfi lburchfi

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 05:44AM awjkej wrote: I am bilateral with no reconstruction too. I am fairly small boned.  This topic has intrigued me for awhile, as I try to reconstruct my wardrobe.  I am not a seamstress, but wish I were!  I was a C cup with breasts, but since I am small boned, my chest area is pretty small.  I will wear the layered look with a tank top, or camisole underneath tshirts, blouses; I look for the ones which are not low cut.  They are sometimes hard to find, so when I find them, I buy a few!  I like to wear them b/c not only do they feel nice, but they give an extra layer, texture. The blouses the I like the best have no darts, and are cut in at the waist (I am sure there is a name for that, but I don't know it!).  Then if I button the shirt up half way, it fits me at the waist, looks more tailored and not baggy. I can buy a v neck shirt or sweater and wear the tank underneath so it covers up the space where my breasts used to fill.  I will buy shirts which have pockets on the front, textured shirts with patterns.  Re the night time, lingerie..I wear tank tops or camisoles with fun bottoms.  I had a cute short slip like item, but the straps were too long with no breasts, so I shortened the straps and it worked. Such an adventure we are on! Anne
Posts.Title: Would you wear this? Diana_B docbob

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 06:13PM awjkej wrote: Hi Kasey, The waiting is the hardest part.  When I get my full body CT/PET scans done (every 3-4 months..I have had 14 so far and I am surprised I am not glowing!), my onc gets the results by the end of the next day.  I usu. wait til my appt with him which is usually scheduled for the following week.  BUT if you are worried and it is too stressful, you can call your onc's nurse and ask that the report be faxed to you, or for the onc to call you with the results before your appt.  Only one time did a tech tell me that she saw the top of me coming through the scan and it looked clear.  Usu they don't say anything and I don't try to question anything in the process otherwise I could second guess myself til the cows come home and I have talked myself into a corner. I have only had one bone scan and that was years ago.  They always do the combo CT/PET scan now which gives a clear picture of what is going on with me.  As some wonderful ladies reminded me earlier today, the aches and pains can be anything and it is the consistent pain that we need to watch out for. Crossing my fingers for good results! Anne

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer and Lung Cancer?? awjkej Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2007 07:07PM awjkej wrote: I believe that the break down in the immune system allows the cancer to grow. I was under a tremendous amount of stress for many years prior to my diagnosis.  While I lived a fairly healthy life, I did not handle my stress properly, or at all.  I also did not sleep very well.   I just assumed that my body could handle anything. My life continue to be stressful, but I am much more diligent about how I react to the stress, and what to do to alleviate it.  I am also much more diligent about getting enough sleep. Now nothing is perfect, but I am more focused on these parts of my life. Anne
Posts.Title: stress and breast cancer shastaw Mizsissy

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2008 11:00AM awjkej wrote: Hi Ladies, I started tykerb and xeloda in August and it took 2 months to figure out the correct dosage and timing.  I experienced a painful rash on my face, and pretty bad hand/foot syndrome where the skin on my feet just basically peeled away.  My hands were very red and dry. But the good news is that now I am NED!  So the 2 months were worth it I guess.  I am currently taking 1000 mg of xeloda, 500mg in morning and 500mg at night, one week on and one week off.  I take tykerb 1000mg nightly along with aromasin. On my off weeks, I have more energy, and my hands are not red.  On my on weeks, my hands get red, my face somewhat and I tire more easily.  No lower gi problems anymore, although they weren't that bad compared to the hand/foot syndrome. I use Bag Balm, and Udderly Smooth Udder cream too...all the time.  My onc told me that after 6 months, which is now, I need to watch for a more chronic hand/foot syndrome side effects, as opposed to the acute side effects I was experiencing last Aug.   So I am on the lookout for sustained dryness and cracking of my hands, but so far so good. Hope this helps and good luck with xeloda..hoping it works as well for you as it is currently for me! Hugs, Anne

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2007 10:04PM awjkej wrote: This is what I do in an attempt to keep my immune up and running -2 oz. wheat grass shots 3-5 times a week -Buy organic when I can -Eat plenty of vegies and fruit -Minimize intake of beef, chicken & pork, and dairy products -Drink 64 oz of water a day -Drink green tea and ginger/lemon tea -No alcohol, caffene, processed sugar -Eat a brazilian nut a day -My treat is dark chocolate and a latte every once in awhile -Supplements:  curcumin & biopherene, green tea extract, grape seed extract, B6 -Listen to Belleruth Naparstak's Affirmation/Visualization CD re chemotherapy/cancer It isn't very exciting, but it helps me to keep my stress low, and to know I am doing what I can to assist in my treatment I hope this helps in some way, Anne
Posts.Title: how can you boost your immune system

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 04:07PM awjkej wrote: Hi, Each tumor/cancer has certain characteristics which determine your treatment.  The following are some of the characteristics involved: Hormone receptor status - you already know that you are positive for estrogen.  You should find out if you are progesterone positive or negative. As mentioned earlier, the "T" drug is tamoxifen which you will take to starve the cancer.  Here is a link from this site with a good explanation of tamoxifen : http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/hormonal/serms/tamoxifen.jsp Her2/neu status - either positive (to what degree) or negative: Lymphnode involvement - ask your surgeon/oncologist if they will be performing a senintel node biopsy when they do the mastectomy.  Why or why not?  The number of lymphnodes involved factor into treatment as well. Histologic Grade of your cancer (this is different from staging) - The Scarff-Bloom-Richardson system is the most common type of cancer grade system used today. To determine a tumor's histologic grade, pathologists examine the breast cancer cells and their patterns under a microscope. Pathologists closely observe three features when determining a cancer's grade: the frequency of cell mitosis (rate of cell division), tubule formation (percentage of cancer composed of tubular structures), and nuclear pleomorphism (change in cell size and uniformity). Each of these features is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 3 (1 indicating slower cell growth and 3 indicating faster cell growth). The scores of each of the cells' features are then added together for a final sum that will range between 3 to 9. Staging will be determined after your mastectomy as the lymphnode involvement will need to be determined. This may seem overwhelming, but I believe knowledge is power, and this information is the start of a better understanding of your treatment and the more knowledge/information you have, gives you the ability to ask questions. I hope this helps. God Bless, Anne
Posts.Title: A question about symptoms bapnkat chemo072

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 07:56PM awjkej wrote: Hi, I had radiation to my left hip for bone mets in 2004 and just finished radiation to my L5 on spine about 2 months ago.  My hip has been NED since radiation and continued treatment.  And my last PET/CT showed NED for my whole body :-).  In both instances, I experienced relief from the pain in short order.  When finished with the rads, I did experience pain again, but it didn't last too long and we chaulked it up to the bones growing again or possibly shifting.  But right now I am feeling pretty good. I had minimal side effects in both instances..no sunburn, some lower GI issues in the beginning and then that subsided.  I did experience fatigue.  I know the docs all say that isn't a side effect, but I have always experienced it but am not sure if it is due to the fact that I had to go every day for a month and that part of the fatigue was due to the emotional part of the rads. I wish you the best and no side effects! Anne

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 05:07AM awjkej wrote: I was on again and off again for xeloda b/c of the hand and foot syndrome...it also went to my face.  After spending 2 months tweaking dosage and timing, I currently take 1000mg of tykerb daily, and xeloda is one week on and one week off, 2 tablets in morning and 2 in evening.  I can handle this dosage for now.  The side effects were just brutal when I was in the thick of it, and I am just happy that that part is over.  My onc has told me that if I cannot tolerate tykerb/xeloda at some point, there are new drugs coming up, and other combinations I haven't tried.  Talk with your oncologist to see what is available for you.  Anne
Posts.Title: XELODA GoldenEyes LoriFL

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 05:52AM awjkej wrote: Hi Ladies, Originally diagnosed with BC in Jan'03 (bilateral, chemo) and then diagnosed with bone mets Oct '04, so have been living with them for 3 years in my left hip and L5 pedicle.  Also had a spot in my hilar region. I was on herceptin (her2/neu+++) from 10/04 to 07/07.  I had taxotere in there for about 8 months too.  I had radiation to my left hip Nov-Dec 2005, and the cancer has been held at bay in my left hip to date :-). I stopped taking herceptin to go on xeloda/tykerb b/c the chest mass was not responding to anything and getting bigger and more active.  The chest mass is gone now too :-). I am also just ending 20 treatments of radiation to the spine.  My most recent PET/CT scan showed increased activity and I had much pain in my lower back-needed narcotic level pain killer.  The PET/CT also showed a small fracture.  Currently the radiation has helped to decrease the pain for which I am grateful.  I truly sympathize with anyone with lower back pain.  It is debilitating to say the very least! I can only monitor my cancer activity with the PET/CT scans which I get 4 times a year to date, and my pain level.  No other scans, blood tests etc. work.  Hang in there, Anne
Posts.Title: Bone mets nursecal awjkej

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2010 11:13PM awjkej wrote: Even though I am on herceptin and tykerb now (have been for 9 months), I am having flashbacks to xeloda and tykerb when I had pain red rash on my face, skin peeling off the bottom of my feet and pain in feet that I had to buy special cushion shoes.  It took 2 months to tweak the dosage and timing of xeloda and tykerb til we managed to get the side effects under control.  I'll never forget my onc's face when I went in for an "emergency" visit to him regarding the side effects...his eyes couldn't have widened any larger!  Herceptin and tykerb isn't so bad, but my fingernails are hideous from the cracking, the red spots just appeared for the first time in 9 month on my face and arms.  So I can count my blessing that I had 9 months of "normalcy"!
Posts.Title: Tykerb questions Fitztwins awjkej

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 11:59PM awjkej wrote: Hi Ladies, I was orig diagnosed in Jan 03.  Had bilateral, 6 rounds of A/C chemo, then put on tamoxifen.  Less than 9 months later, I experienced a pretty bad back pain.  Had xray of my right hip..nothing.  Month later had xray of waist down and it showed bone mets in my spine.  Then had bone scan..showed nothing.  PET/CT scan showed uptake in my spine, left hip and spot on my chest. So I started herceptin and was on it for 2 1/2 years, had my ovaries out, have also been on: taxotere faslodex, arimidex, aromasin rads to spine rads to hip zometa monthly for 2 years, now every 3 months Currently am on xeloda/tykerb, aromasin, zometa. I also do 2 oz wheat grass shots 4-5 times a week.  I take calcium with Vit.D, curcumin, green tea extract, grape seed extract, biopherene. If the pain is constant or gets worse then you should get it checked out with your oncologist.  The only scans that work for me are the PET/CT scans....I have had them every 3-4 months...13 of them so far.  My last PET scan showed for the first time NED!  Still sinking in and I hope I can keep this trend going for awhile :-). I hope this helps.  Hugs, Anne
Posts.Title: How was your bone mets diagnosed Danie awjkej

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 12:23PM awjkej wrote: Hi JoyRebbeca, I was diagnosed with bone mets in Oct 2004, original diagnosis of BC January 2003.  I have had to learn over time how my body reacts to the BC e.g. what pains mean what.  The rule of thumb is that if the pain becomes consistent or more intense then I have to pay attention to it. I am 47, so I also have "normal aches and pains", but it is learning that I could have a pain that lasts 3 days or even a week, and then it goes away.  But it is the panic feeling of what if this means it is coming back that never goes away. The other piece for me is that as LuAnn mentioned there are other options for you...there are other options for me.  I don't take much for granted anymore, but the one luxury I allow myself is to believe that with all the research and advances in treatment, that I will have options for treatment if my current one doesn't work.  With almost 5 years from initial diagnosis and coming from a not so great prognosis, I tell myself that I am going to be around a long time treating my BC as a chronic disease. So hang in there, know that you aren't alone, and that you have many options! Anne
Posts.Title: tumor markers JoyRebecca JoyRebecca

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 06:39PM awjkej wrote: Danie, Tumor marker blood tests don't work for me.  My results always came back in the normal range, and clearly I had bone mets. So we don't do them anymore.  My onc said that they usu. try the tumor marker tests to see if they will help in the evaluation process.  Clearly mine don't.  So it isn't unusual to not have them done. I added a comment to your other thread (I mispelled your name, my apologies!) regarding the second opinion.  I totally support you getting a second opinion, and also changing oncologists if you can! Anne
Posts.Title: How was your bone mets diagnosed Danie awjkej

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 11:30PM awjkej wrote: Hi, When I started, I had TERRIBLE hand/foot syndrome, and also a very painful and red rash on my face (I tried everything from Crisco to Bag Balm, and ended up icing my face to keep the pain down).  I started at 2 weeks on, one week off with xeloda.  I would have to stay off the drugs til everything cleared up and then start again at a different dosage.  Through trial and error adjustments I am currently on one week on, one week off for xeloda at 2000 mg, and 1000mg of tykerb daily. My onc told me that xeloda is most effective days 1-7 and then after that you are just dealing with side effects.  Doing one week on, one week off, has practically eliminated the hand/foot syndrome. It is worth asking your onc about it. Anne
